awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PIPP Workshop: Pandemic Readiness for Emerging Pathogens(PREP) to be Held February 15-19, 2021.
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund the Pandemic Readiness for Emerging Pathogens (PREP) workshop, planned for February 15-19, 2021. The PREP workshop will foster scientific discussion and catalyze innovation and partnerships to enhance our understanding of the challenges and potential solutions to rapid detection and assessment of emerging pathogens and infectious disease dynamics from the molecular to the ecological scale. Four panel topics are planned for this workshop: (1) The Challenges in Rapid and Accurate Detection and Assessment of Emerging Pathogens; (2) Approaches to Rapid and Accurate Detection and Assessment of Emerging Pathogens; (3) Monitoring Animal and Human Movements, High-Risk Interfaces for Disease Transmission, and At-risk Communities; (4) Data-Intensive Machine Learning and Modelling for Pandemic Preparedness. By integrating expertise in new sensor engineering, epidemiology, wildlife, and human health, ecology, quantitative social sciences, evolutionary biology, engineering, and computer science, new approaches in modeling, computational mathematics, data-enabled predictive science and decision making, and real-time intelligent sensing will be identified to transform infectious disease outbreak prediction capabilities. Subsequent to the workshop, the organizers plan to prepare reports summarizing the workshop for publication in high-profile general science outlets which can be used to inform the development of predictive intelligence for pandemic prevention.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nature of Project:

The NSF Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention (PIPP) Workshop on Pandemic Readiness for Emerging Pathogens (PREP) was held on Feb 16 and 17, 2021, in a virtual online setting open to all interested registrants. With more than 750 participants from academia, government, industry, and non-governmental organizations, this PIPP-PREP workshop brought together top experts engaged in research relevant to advancing rapid pathogen detection, biosensing, and the tracking of human and animal populations for the purpose of risk modeling and pandemic preparedness. Research disciplines were drawn from the purview of the following four NSF directorates: Engineering (ENG), Biological Sciences (BIO), Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE), and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE).   

Keynote strategic vision presentations were paired from disparate disciplines, and invited panelists, and breakout discussions were designed to encourage broad participation across the workshop. The program of the workshop was focused around four key themes related to predictive intelligence for pandemic preparedness: 1) Rapid and Accurate Detection and Assessment of Emerging Pathogens, 2) Monitoring Environmental Change, Animal Movements, and High-Risk Interfaces for Disease Transmission, 3) Monitoring Human Movements and At-risk Communities for Disease Transmission and Spread, and 4) Data-Intensive Machine Learning and Modeling for Pandemic Preparedness.

This workshop aimed to catalyze interest in trans-disciplinary research for predictive intelligence through a highly engaged meeting with invited speakers and participants to help identify grand challenges and research priorities for pandemic prevention. 

Major Outcomes:

This workshop articulated the cross-disciplinary approach and the transformative research priorities needed to tackle and preempt pandemic threats. This includes the design of novel educational and training programs to ensure a properly informed workforce with communication skills that will facilitate engagement in team science spanning disparate disciplines, and the incorporation of research evaluation strategies that foster high-risk/high-payoff approaches and allow for a longer timescale for achieving results. As such, strategies to evaluate cross-disciplinary team-science and determine the efficacy of translation from research outcomes to public policy will be crucial to this endeavor.

This workshop identified several Grand Challenges for Predictive Intelligence as high priority knowledge gaps and technical needs that will advance pandemic prevention. Within the scope of rapid detection of emerging pathogens, new sensor modalities and autonomous detection of pathogens with innovative application of sensing technologies and machine learning for improved accuracy of sensors were prioritized. Research needs were also identified to improve monitoring of environmental change, animal movements, and human movements to enhance biosurveillance at high-risk interfaces for disease transmission, that similarly involve autonomous sensing platforms for characterizing movements and land use that address biases and privacy concerns. Data challenges were described as related to sparsity of data and multimodal complex structures of data inherent to trans-disciplinary research. Innovative integration of a range of expertise in cross-disciplinary research will be needed to address these challenges with assessment strategies for determining the efficacy of translation from research to public policy.
